options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar and lecture.
Live virtual lecture with virtual seminar discussion
In person seminar with lectures at the beginning.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned the basics and mechanisms of human skill learning, as well as some scientific methods
Learned a lot in this course about different kinds of skill learning and the mechanisms behind it

Learned about implicit vs explicit skill learning, specifically in relation to motor skill learning. We looked at foundational concepts such as classical and operant conditioning and the landmark studies associated with learning. Then, we built onto topics such as savings, the idea of practice, and concepts associated with learning.

I learned about the mechanisms by which humans and others acquire skills and how those different types of learning can be applied from everything to language learning to athletic skill to the development of AI. The class starts at basic Pavlovian conditioning and builds from there until you gradually acquire a complex understanding of what psychological and neurological processes are at play when you learn.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Fantastic teacher and interesting class material. Written notes or a more cohesive course structure with easier formats to review lecture/discussion material could improve overall comprehension of material. It is easy to forget information, particularly virtually.

Sam is very understanding and generous, and his energy is great. You learn a lot. However, the grading structure is very strange. more than half of your grade come in the last few weeks of classes with a presentation, a paper, and a final exam. This class would be much better if the weekly submissions are worth more.
Great course overall, professor was very engaged and friendly

Strengths: Having weekly reading responses was great. The format of synchronous classes kept me engaged since half the class period was dedicated to lecture and half was dedicated to discussion. I enjoyed having that separation in every class. Not many standout strengthshuman skill learning is a standard but engaging psychology seminar. It was well organized for online learning for sure.

Weaknesses: Since lecture time was only half the class period, it felt very rushed at times and it seemed like we were trying to fit too much material into a short period. We also talked in class about how the workload was heavily skewed towards the end of the semester, which wasn't a problem for me but could be a con for other schedules.

Strengths: Papers and material in general are really interesting, manageable workload, Sam is a really good discussion leader and always available to help/chat.

Weaknesses: Sometimes the lectures felt a tad rushed, which made it occasionally challenging to follow exactly what was happening. Got better as the semester went on, though.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had very interesting discussions and lectures. Just please don't have a group work when everyone is online, it's very difficult to coordinate.

Loved the separation between dedicated time for lecture and dedicated time for discussion since online learning can be a drag. It was a great course for learning during the pandemic and all the assignments (weekly responses, group research project etc.) were accessible wherever you were tuning in from.

I thought the idea of a 10-15 min break between the lecture and seminar was really nice, since it gave everyone time to refocus and take a break from the draining nature of Zoom. Was a bit difficult to do a group project without having the ability to meet up in person, but that can't really be helped.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, although some administrative of this course might be frustrating, you learn a lot.
Yes, take this course!
Yes
Yes I would recommend this course if a student was interested in this topic.
Yes, great course!

Yes, Sam is a great professor who was super approachable and was cognizant of the struggles of online learning (which I'm sure translating to in-person semesters as well). I wouldn't expect to be completely mind-blown or to develop a new world-view from this course, but it is a standard psychology seminar class. If you've taken the human brain, some of the neuroscience concepts we go over in class may be review. workload is also very manageable so would consider adding as 5th class.
Yes! If you're looking for an upper-level psych/neuro class to take that is really interesting and won't overwhelm you, would definitely recommend.
